title: Sexual violence and harassment cases at universities treble in three years
text:
Sexual violence and harassment cases at universities have trebled in three years, as victims reveal their claims are being investigated by novices.

Universities recorded 1,436 allegations of sexual harassment or sexual violence against students in 2018-19, up from 476 in 2016-17, according to figures obtained under freedom of information laws by the BBC.

Of the 124 universities that provided information, just 33 confirmed they used specialist investigators to interview students making claims.

One student told the BBC how she felt “retraumatised” when was interviewed by university staff about being raped. She said that it felt like being “interrogated” as she was asked detailed intimate questions and quizzed over her mental health.

Earlier this year, Warwick University’s vice-Chancellor apologised over the institution’s handling of the Facebook rape group chat scandal. The admission came after an independent review found the incident had left a "legacy of mistrust" at the university.

Prof Stuart Croft said the university has overhauled its disciplinary procedures following the backlash from students, staff and alumni over the incident and its aftermath.

An independent review it commissioned into its handling of the case described how Warwick’s director of press and media had initially been appointed to handle the complaints process.
